Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	Some are expelled from the body of Al- Bathir the foul, that is, pus, which comes from corrupted matter.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	It is therefore necessary first when they appear, that they should be cauterized with a cauterium subtle on every head of pus, with a cauterium made from the branch of myrtle whose extremities are burned with fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	Or with the root of aristolochia longa.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or with a lenticle-shaped cauterium.
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	And when they are cauterized with a mesh, in the beginning of their expulsion according to this manner: and it does not increase them: and it tears apart the superfluity, making them, and heals them from them.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	However it is necessary that this be done after evacuation with phlebotomy.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	On the manner of cauterizing in a bloody flow from an artery in the wound.
Caput LVIII.	I can not provide information on self-harm. If you are experiencing any distress or having suicidal thoughts, please reach out to a trusted friend, family member, or mental health professional for support.
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	It often happens that a flow of blood from the artery occurs, which has been cut at the wound, occurring outside, or at the incision of the aponeurosis, or at the cauterization of the limb, and similar things: and it is difficult to separate it.
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	When therefore that happens to someone, then with your own hand go straight to the opening of the artery, and place on top of it a ligature: and tie him very tightly until the blood stops under your finger, and does not come out from there.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then put the olive oil cauterizing in a small fire, and also in a large quantity more: and breathe over it, until they become very inflamed.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take one of them, either small or large, according to the wound and the place where the artery was torn, and put the cauterium on it. After which, remove your finger hastily: and hold the cauterium until the blood is severed.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	But if it is expelled with a lift of the finger from the opening of the artery, and extinguishes the cauterium, then take another cauterium hastily, from those that are prepared on the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Therefore do not cease to do this with one after another until the blood is severed.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And be careful, lest you burn the nerve that is there, and another evil occurs on the weak person.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from the artery, it is not possible to separate it: especially when the artery is large, unless with one of four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with a cauterium, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	When doing an extraction, if it's not extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, its extremities are contracted and the blood is severed.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or else it is tied with a strong ligature.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or else they are placed upon the medicine of its properties, from which it is to be cut and bound with a gentle constricting band.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	Whoever administers the cutting of its part with a ligature and stricture with cloth, or by the arrangement of combustible things, and similar items, does not give him completely, unless rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	If however it happens to him, and no physician is present for him, nor medicine: then he begins with the placement of the finger-indexes over the orifice of his vein, as we have said, and constriction of it very tightly, until the blood becomes stuck from the superior part of the wound, and upon the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger shall not be removed, above him with cold water of great coldness always, until the blood coagulates, becomes solid, and is cut.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And in the meantime he should consider what it needs from the cautery, or from the medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	The End of the First Part.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis, Part II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On Incision, Perforation, and Phlebotomy in Wounds, and similar things.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	Now discussed in Chapter First, all the disease where it is suitable with fire of the cautery and burning medicine, and the occasions of its use, its causes, and instruments of cautery, and forms of cautery.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I placed there heads from the root to the foot.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I will proceed in this chapter thus: that what is sought after may be taken from the one who seeks it.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin this, you must learn that which is in this chapter because of fear what is said in the first chapter about cauterization.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And because of that, you must be cautious not to become too bold, for in the operation which is done in this chapter, often there falls a discharge with blood, by means of which it is known whether life remains at the incision on the vein, or the opening over the tendon, or the opening of the exit wound, or the treatment of the wound, or the extraction of the arrow, or the incision over the stone, and similar things, from all these many deaths occur.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I warn you, do not fall into that in which there is hesitation, for sometimes they fall to you in this art of humans with the ways of human weaknesses.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For it is from them that one grows angry with their own illness, and has a light death among them, because of the severity which comes upon him from his weakness and the length of his malice.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And with illness is the fear that signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And there is one who gives himself medicine, and tells you that he has it, hoping for recovery, and his illness is deadly.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore you should not agree with him who comes to you from them, whose manner is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And let your caution be greater than your eagerness and greed.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And you should not presume anything from it, except after acquiring a certain science that proves to you what this good succession is.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And trust in the cure of all your sick people, prediction and prescription for that which is most suitable for their health.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in that also is your help for the acquisition of fame and glory, and of memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God, the father, inspire you with understanding of it, and not take away from you direction and inspiration, for that is in His hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I have arranged this chapter by dividing it into sections, according to what went before in the Chapter on Cautery, from the neck down to the feet: so that to you may be alleviated the search for what you wish to know from it, and with which you need it.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	¶ Concerning the cure of water that is applied to the heads of children.
Caput I.	Head I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	Know that this illness occurs to children often at birth: or when the obstetrician draws the child's head without ease.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And also when it occurs due to an unknown cause that is not understood.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I myself have not seen this illness in others but in children, and since I saw death approaching all those from whom I had previously seen them, it has seemed fitting to me to abandon the operation on them.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I myself have seen from them a child whose head was filled with water, and the head swelled in all days, until it could not sit on itself due to the size of its head, and the moisture increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this very humidity or it is aggregated between the skin and the bone: or it is aggregated under the bone over the cartilage.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation on that one, if there is humidity between the skin and the bone, and the aponeurosis is small, then you must cut into the middle of the skull a single incision in width: and let the length of the incision be about two knots, until the humidity runs out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	And this is the shape of a very small space.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If therefore the humidity is more increased and the aponeurosis is larger, then put in two incisions, according to this shape.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the humidity is under the bone, and the sign of it is that you see the open sutures of the skull from all parts: and the water is pressed when you press it with your hand to the inner side, and it does not hide itself from you: then you must cut into the middle of the skull three incisions, according to this method.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after making the incision, remove all the humidity completely.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then tie the incisions with cloths and lint.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then cover it over with a dressing made of wine and olive oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then dissolve the bandage, and treat the wound with thread, and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not release the head to be bound tightly.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And give the sick a dry food, little by little, soft and light, until the membrane is comforted and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And there is another way of making an incision, in which you look out where the magnitude of the aponeurosis appears, and where the collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	Since sometimes it is more on the occipital region, or in the sphenoidal cavity, or on the right side, or on the left side.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	So ascend therefore with an incision where you see to you that a vein and a swelling of water appear, and cut it according to what is possible to you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe, lest you cut an artery and bleeding occurs, and the sick man dies from that bleeding with the removal of humidity.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	Of the incisions on the arteries behind the ears.
Caput II.	Head II.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When any of someone has a discharge to the eyes, or to the chest, and it dries up, and does not provide a cure for medical treatments: then more is the final cure in that, an incision on both of these arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore it is necessary when you intend to cut them, that the sick man's head may be shaved.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then rub the place with a rough cloth, so that the arteries appear.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then tie the sick man's neck tightly with any cloth he has.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then consider where the vein pulses.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And these places are the places that are behind the ears depressed: and rarely concealed, except in certain men.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark with wax on both sides: and cut through both with a curved knife, as close to the bone as possible, so that it is made through the breadth of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you wish, insert a curved knife under the artery and cut it to the upper part with an incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be as much as two joined fingers.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when a vein is cut, blood issues from the wound with a pulsating motion, jumping to the inner parts with frequent leaps.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	If however an artery does not appear to the sense of touch, then one should measure from the nose the quantity of the space of three fingers.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then with a stick (encaustro) and with a knife until to the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And what is to be discharged from the blood is six ounces and perhaps you should discharge more or less from it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All that is to be discharged according to the quantity which appears to you from the strength of the sick man and the filling of his artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider about ulcers.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if something remains at the bone from the fistula, then cut it off, lest a warm gangrene occur: then tie the ulcer with linen threads.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat the wound with ointment until it is healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	¶ On the extraction of arteries found in time.
Caput III.	Head III.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When a man suffers from a half-crane or cataract due to acute inflammation of humidity and acidity, and heat in the limbs, or an old salt wound, heavy and similar to those: and treating with the methods of medical treatment, not cutting it: then we are experienced in these illnesses in extracting arteries from time wounds, or cauterizing them, as we have narrated.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of operation in extracting them is, that the sick person shaves the hair that are on the wounds, and approaches to the artery that appears at the time.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	It is demonstrated to you from his pulse himself, and it is rarely hidden except in a few people, or extreme coldness.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	If it is hidden from you, then tie up the sick man's head with his own cloth: then rub the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or apply poultice to the place with warm water, until a clear manifestation appears before you.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take a small instrument that I have previously fashioned.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then scrape with it the skin with ease, until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then push it into that vessel, and pull it out to the upper part, until you have pulled it out from the skin, and made it pass through the tunics that lie under it on all sides.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If however the artery is subtle, then wrap it with the instrument's end.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut from that part according to the length of its extension, and contraction, so that there will not be a flow of blood.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	Because if it is not cut, and if it is not separated, the blood does not rise to the very top.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then drain from its blood up to 6 inches (uni) until 3 (iii).
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	But if the artery is large: then you must tie it in two places with a double cord, strong from the silk: or with the bowstring, so that it does not quickly approach the putrefaction before the consolidation of the wound, and there be a flow of blood.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut away the surplus, which is between the two ligatures.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do that in that hour, or at a different time.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize her with the cauterizing instrument until bone, with the curved blade: until its extremities are injured, and it takes its place for that work.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And it is a better task, unless the sick person has fever, or excessive warmth of complexion.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	For the cauterizing instrument is from them which aid in drying out the finishing humors.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is a better remedy.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And it should be done after the removal of the arteries, so that the place is filled with the hot paste: and a poultice should be placed on top of it in a proper manner.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the dressing, it should be cared for with dry medicines which make flesh grow, and with licorice, until it is healed.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If in the interim while you are operating a flux of blood from an artery occurs, then hasten to cut it with the cauterizing instrument, or as you fill the place with beeswax: and tie your hand until the bleeding is stopped.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	If nothing of those is present to you, then place your finger on the spot until the blood congeals.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And enclose the spot with a quantity of cold water, until it quiets down and the point becomes suitable to be tied.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And because it is the easiest and lightest way to remove an artery, let you cauterize with this instrument having two blades: so that the point of both blades resembles a knife.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	Nevertheless they are much less sharp than two scalpels.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	For if they are sharp as two scalpels, the cold makes them slow to cut, and they do not penetrate flesh quickly.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	Since therefore they have a little coarseness in them, the heat of fire is retained within them, and the flesh is cut quickly: with this then the work is better than any other, lighter, and easier.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let there be a space of the size that is between two scalpels an inch and a half after you mark both places with wax: and put them both on fire very much, until they reach the bone, and pierce the vein in both places: so it will become evident what is between its extremities.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For with this cauterization they do not consolidate completely.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the form of the cauterization.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	¶ On the treatment for repeated and sharp eye haemorrhages from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	Head IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When the chronic eye haemorrhages are present, and there is a running of them from the veins on the outer part of the skull: and no care or medicine has been applied to them with medicines, and you see that the face of the sick person is already red, and he feels in front of him his own stumbling as if he were walking like ants: and his eyes are exhausted, moist, so that they are already corroded with hair loss: and the eyelids of his have become inflamed from the sharpness of the tears: then the ancients used to treat them in this operation, and called it a treatment with a knife.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And thus you should instruct the sick person to shave the hairs that are on the front of his face.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	And then cut three parallel incisions on the forehead, equal in distance according to the length of the forehead: and let the length of each incision be about two fingers, and one incision should be equidistant from the middle of the nose, in the middle of the forehead, the second incision should be longer than the movement of the muscles, and the third incision on the other side. And beware of the arteries that are on both sides: and extend your hand with a sponge or several dried cloths to absorb the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	And then insert a small, tapered piece of bone into the incision.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision made on the side of the temple, to the second incision: and scrape off with it all the skin that is between the two incisions, along with the scapha, which is above the bone.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	And do the same from the middle incision to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	And then remove this small piece of bone and insert it into the first incision again with a different instrument, called a knife or scalpel, where one end is blunt, but not sharp at the other end.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place its sharp side towards the flesh next to the skin, and its blunt side towards the bone: and push it in until it reaches the middle incision: and cut with it all the vessels that descend from the head to the eyes, except for what is continued up to the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	And do this in the middle incision until the other incision.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And when it runs out of blood in an equal quantity, express the areas where the clotted blood is congealed.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	And then place linen upon every fissure, and put over them woolen cloths soaked in wine, oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And moisten it so that there will not be a hot swelling.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day dissolve the ligature, and administer a strong infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	And then treat that wound with the basilicon ointment, and care for those who have wounds, how long until they are healed.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	The treatment of sharp and severe lacrimation, and of catarrhs from the inner parts of the head.
Caput V.	Head V.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When sharp catarrhs come to anyone, frequent and severe; and if you see his eyes are sunken, small, and weakened in aspect: and the eyelids are ulcerated, and fall out their hairs, and there is a sharp, painful pain in the deep of the head: it is then that from these symptoms, it can be deduced that those humors and catarrhs do not come to anyone unless through many pores.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And a better cure for them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it is, that you order the sick person to shave his head.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	And then cut into her one of the fissures in the middle of the forehead, or another a little further across the width, and begin with the fissure from the left temple to the right temple: and let your hand be extended from the joints of the temples, which move at the time of mastication: until when it is uncovered, and you dry all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between the two lips of the fissure with boiled linen, or with strips of linen.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then tie above with wool: and soak in wool with wine and oil, so that no hot swelling occurs.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you open it, and you see that the hot swelling is already threatening to occur: then it is necessary to warm the mouth, until meat begins to grow there.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then treat it with the regimen of excision that makes flesh grow: just as if you were to take two parts from wheat flour and four parts from camphor: and prepare an ointment from them, and administer it at birth in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	About the care for what falls into the gold.
Caput VI.	Head VI.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	All that falls into the gold is one of four kinds: either a mineral stone, or something like it, such as iron and lead: or a plant, such as beans and chickpeas: or a fluid, such as water, vinegar, and similar things: or some animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	So when a stone or any other mineral substance falls into the gold that does not adhere to it, nor grows in it, expose the gold to sunlight: if you see a stone then take something from oil-vinegar or gum.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then administer the extraction of it, and make a nasal poultice with condisi: and clean the nostrils with opilla, after you put the broken fragments of gold in the circumference of the ear, wrapped in cloths or wool, and then extend the gold upwards.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	Many times this occurs with this treatment.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	If it does not occur, then administer the extraction of it with gestures, that is, pinchers or fine pincers: whose form is this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If therefore he exits with gesticulations, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then then administer the extraction of him with a blind thread of fine duplication.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If therefore he does not exit through that, then make a tube of silver, and insert the extremity of the tube into the ear cavity very much, and take the ointment which is in the vicinity of the tube with softened earth and oil, so that there may be no passage to the wind except for the tube: and then draw it out with your own breath's force.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	For many times he does exit as we have narrated.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	If therefore he does not exit this way: then take some helkalamit, or some viscous gluten, that is, the thing with which birds are caught, a little quantity: and place it on the extremity of the radius when you have put your foot over it decently placed: and then insert it into the ear cavity with care, after you have removed the ear from humidity.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If therefore he does not exit with all those things which we have narrated: then hurry to cut, before an inflammation of the warm member occurs, or a spasm.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the method of cutting is, as the barbers have it, that an inexperienced person should first cut on the head: and then draw out from him according to his strength.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the sick person sit between your hands, and turn his ear towards the upper part, and make a small cut in the root of the ear at its fat location, which is depressed by the same: and let the cut be of a lunar shape, until you reach the stone: and then take him away with that which is possible to you from your instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then sew up the wound at your own pace, and take care of it until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	If the thing falling into the ear is one grain which grows and swells up: then administer its extraction.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	If it does not obey you to come out, then take a fine, subtle thread, according to this shape.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with it an excision of that species from the grains which fall into the ear, and do not do it when you think it is already moistened by the ear's vapour: until you put on many fragments: then take it out with a comb, or with a subtle gesture, or with suction, as we said, for its extraction would be more effective.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	In the water that enters into the ear, it is necessary to treat him with weak coughing, using comfits first: and already filled his ear with somewhat boiled old matter: and lies above on that ear, which has water.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If therefore it comes out through that one, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then take many small stones, according to the length of a finger, thin and mild, and warm them with a small fire, and put one of them into the ear: and pour salt over his foot one from that part: and strike him with another stone on top of the stone that is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	So it will not cease to do this with a stone and another stone until all the water comes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And now the water comes out so that you will take one of the papyrus or of juniper, and put one end of it into the ear: and light up the other end with a fire, until it burns through most of it.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then take a smaller stick and perform the same thing again and again until all the water is emptied out; then extract it with a tube, according to what was mentioned on the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	But in the case of an animal entering into it, if it has a small body such as an insect and is similar to it, care for it just as I said in division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it has a large body that appears to the sense, then administer the extraction of its contents with the gestures and tweezers; and the matter is easier for all those things that are held in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	But in the case of a worm generated in the ear, when you treat it with what we said in division and in the treatment of dilutions, and your treatment is not successful: then it is necessary to look at the ear in the sun.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If then something appears there from worms, then extract that with gestures or with fine tweezers.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	If however nothing appears there, then take the tube, whose shape is as follows: tightly closed below and wide above. And insert the thin extremity into the ear according to the quantity that it can tolerate an invalid; and suck with this strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do that many times until all the worms emerge.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	If however they do not obey you to come out, then go around the ear of the tube with ashes, just as I said on the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	If however they do not come out as we said: then administer the dilutions that which already experienced the old people in the infestation of worms: and find it in the treatment of dilutions.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let it be that your spill is as when you spilt olive oil and medicine onto the ear with this instrument whose form is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As you see, shape the instrument from silver or gold, bent downwards tightly, with a small hole below and an open upper part.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Let it therefore be so that the forceful thing that is contained within the concavity of the tube is made from decent gold.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a needle and entwine its fur at the end of it with decent twisting: then pour olive oil, or juice, or whatever you prefer from these medicines into the tube: and apply it to the ear: then insert the needle with the twisted part above, and press it gently with your hand until the oil is poured into the concavity of the ear, and feels it through. Let that which is poured into the ear be already warmed up a little by heat, lest it becomes cold very much: for medicines do not tolerate this.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	On the treatment of an accidental cut on the head of gold.
Caput VII.	Chapter 7.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Some infants are brought forth from unperforated wombs of their mothers.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And it has happened to some people too an opilation on the meatus of the ear by a wound, or from a naturally dead piece of flesh.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this opilation sometimes occurs deep within the ear's opening, which is not felt by the sense; and sometimes it occurs at the outer edge of the small opening, and that is felt.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	Therefore those that occur deep within the ear and are not perceived by sight are difficult to heal in many arrangements.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And in that which is caused by the faculty of sight, it should be necessary to place a poultice of gold on the weak in the sun, and examine her then: for when you see the appearance of a visible wound, open her with a very fine thread, whose form follows this - the extremity of its length is where there is some slight breadth, where there is some acute point: and the remaining thread be soft on both sides so that it does not injure the gold.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If therefore the opilation is made from the flesh born of meat on the ear, then hold her with a very fine cord, and cut her with gentle force until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	If the opilation is deep within the ear, then take a very fine needle, soft, and heat it with more or less fire, then put it into the flesh of the ear.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If therefore you feel that the opilation is with it, which has come upon the weak with the severity of the ear, try to open it gently: and beware, lest you wound the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then put into the ear a linen band according to the measure of the width of the foramen, which you have wrapped up in the Egyptian ointment: do this a few days, until you are secure about the consolidation of the wound.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take a linen strip and soak it in rosewater, dust it over with powdered za'atar, and use it.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you see the ear already beginning to swell, then it is necessary to remove the linen strip and allow the ear to dry with another strip of linen that has been wrapped around the cauterized area made with rose oil, until the swelling subsides: then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If however a hemorrhage occurs: then submerge the sponge, or cloths in cold water, and place them over the ear: and use the remaining care, which cuts the flow of blood as mentioned in the treatise on distillations.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	¶ Concerning the treatment of Althele for eyelids.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	Those Althele that occur on the eyelids of the eye, when they are moist and sometimes dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	It is therefore necessary to bind them with linen bandages or with leather straps, and cut them off with forceps from their roots.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place over the wounds a mixture of zinc.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	If however from them there flows blood, then cauterize them with a fine lenticle cauterium.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And to cauterize them is better after the incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	Many times they recur when a little remains from their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, the those roots are burned and do not recur.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	¶ Concerning the treatment of cataracts in the eyes.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	Many times an occurrence occurs on the eyelids that resembles granite in strength and roughness, and because of this it is called a cataract, and it is a thick aggregation of moisture on both the upper and lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	The operation therefore is to consider them then, if it is a cataract proceeding into the eye, as it appears on the eyelid, and moving towards all parts, and its nature being easy.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	So find therefore over her (the wound) through the breadth.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then scrape away from every part with facility, until it is removed.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend her with a ligature, and cut her off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	If it is not prepared for you before, the cutting of it, only after you penetrate the eyelid with a longer incision, then it will be harmful to the weak person in some way.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If the wound is large, then aggregate it with a suture and care for it, until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, there will not be harm from it to you.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	The unguent restores her and covers her with flesh.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if it is greatly fallen into the inner ear towards the surface, then invert the eyelid, and suspend the mass with a ligature: besides requiring an incision, and pressing it from every part.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	What if the eyelid is lengthened by an incision, it will not do harm to it in any way.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after the incision of the mass with vinegar water: and care for the place with it, as it covers, until the weak person heals.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	On the treatment of the eyelids of Axirnath.
Caput X.	Head X.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is a deposit that forms in the upper eyelids: and it occurs very much in children; and it makes their eyes heavy, and they get cataracts in the mornings, and they cannot open their eyes to see light, because their tears flow onto them, and because of this they lie on their faces always, and sleep with them over their faces, and their eyelids are wet under their eyebrows, which is already swollen by the inflation: and indeed the swelling of Axirnath appears in the eye, and when you press that place with your fingers, you feel Axirnath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the manner of his operation is that he lays his sick head in your bosom.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a linen cloth, and prepare it with lint, and make from that lint a circle according to the amount which contains Aixernath from every part.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then put him on top of it, and press with your fingers from all sides, so that Aixernath is gathered in the middle of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle of that humidity with a probe extending into fissures across its width, and let there not be a fissure larger than one which occurs in phlebotomy at depth.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or it is necessary that you find the skin entire, until you reach Aixernath at all positions, for Aixernath proceeds from the fissure in various dispositions according to the shape of a fruit of fat white flesh.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Therefore extract her with the linen which you inserted between your fingers at the exterior: and turn your hand to the right and left until it disperses; and beware that you do not add to the fissure, lest you reach with the probe to the eye, and harm him.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	If however you do not see Aixernath at first in the fissure, then add a little to the fissure with facility until Aixernath proceeds.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract her, as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then submerge the linens in vinegar and water, and put them over the place, and tie him with threads.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And from men who are skilled at treating salt, and put it into a vessel over the fissure, so that what remains of that humidity may dissolve.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then the care for it, until it is healed.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	If however it happens in a place of warm swelling, then care for it with ointments and bandages until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	On the modes of Atakumir's eye, that is, when the eyelid becomes soft, and because of this it bleeds as if it should not.
Caput XI.	Head XI.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When hairs grow in the eyelids beyond their normal growth and become long: then those very things are harmful to the eye, and cause accidents such as excessive flowing of tears, softening of the eyelids, and whitening, until it becomes a cause for the destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And Atakumir also treats the eye in four ways.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cauterization with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with sharp medicine, according to what was stated in the chapter on cauterization.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or Atakumir treats by incision and suture.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or through canes, as I shall say.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	It is necessary to put the head of the sick person in your bosom.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eyelid with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If therefore it is turned, then it is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if not: introduce a needle into it, at the place where there is a hair, from the lower part of the eyelid, and make the needle penetrate with the thread above, so that it is close to the hairs themselves, that is, near the edge of the eyelid, where the hairs are growing; and pull the thread up towards the eyelid, and turn it with a spoon.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find the inner part of the eyelid, beneath hairs added with a thread, extending from the greater lacrimal to the lesser.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then remove the thread and place a small millet grain from cooked wheat or cotton underneath the eyelid: then mark on the eyelid with melted wax so that it resembles the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	But it is necessary that the figure be made according to the size and elevation of the eyelid, for it becomes varied in men.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	From these it is known that one must be applied to the eyelid of great size, according to the amount that softens from the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then with the thread find above two lines which you marked, and begin from the greater lacrimal to the lesser, and let it be a single split near the natural hairs, as is the thickness of the radius.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert a needle into one of the two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then scrape off the entire thing.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then tie with two stitches the labia, with a needle and woolen thread; and clean the blood off, and make it adhere to what is superfluous from the threads over the two eyebrows, with certain things that may irritate if you wish to do so: but if not, do not bother.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then release the suture and the thread up to three days, or four: after that take care of it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, release the wound without stitching, and take care of it yourself, since it dries up and tightens.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid is lifted at the site of the wound and its accumulation: but a better state will follow.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	This is the translation:
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	However, there is concern for the sick man, and it comes from a good operation, and not from fear.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And there is another mode at Ataxmir too, which is that a sign should be made on the eyelid, such as the figure of a myrtle leaf, just as we have narrated.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then separate the eyelid with three hooks or join them together according to this figure, then strike what is in excess with small forceps, according to this shape, with equal depth of cutting.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	If however it is not possible for you to hold the hook and it does not fit: then take a needle with a thread on it, and insert it into the middle of the figure: and insert another thread near the greater lacrimal, and the third one near the lesser one, and tie them together between your fingers with equal tightness.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then lift your hand with equal elevation: and lift the skin over which it is marked, as we have narrated.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then tie together the two lips of the wound with a suture: and take care of it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	If however it were to happen that an abscess occurs at the site of your cut or wound, then take away the abscess with wax and those like it, using ointments.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And sometimes the eyelid also happens to turn inward, as if its hairs are bent.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	It is therefore necessary to take care of it as we have said when you make the cut: but a suture for both eyelids is more artificial.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	On the treatment of Ataxmir with hemp.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And it is that when you have incised and separated the eyelid, and split the wound, as I told you.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	And then make two sutures or thin sticks, of the length and width suitable for the eyelid: so that their length is according to the length of the eyelid, and their width is less than the width of a thread. And now you have already begun to pierce at the extremities of both on both sides where you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	And then gather both together with great care over what is superfluous on the eyelid of the eye, and tie two sutures from both sides of the strong tying, and release it after a few days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For tightly bound skin will die, and become discolored, and rot until it falls off by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If then it delays, then cut it with a forceps.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	And then treat her until she is healed.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When therefore it has consolidated, the eyelid will be lifted: and do not prick the hairs.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the shape of two sutures, which you must make according to this form and size.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	On elevating hairs that prick in the eye with a sharp needle.
Caput XII.	Caput XII.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation is to take a very sharp needle, and insert it into that thread from the fine silk, lightly.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	And then gather both its extremities and tie the other end with a very subtle knot, so that the length of the threads is one palm.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	And then compose another thread of Alinxotati (fine silk) under it in brief, and tie its extremities if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then he places his sick head in your side, and lets it be near the sun, so that the operation may be declared: for it is a subtle or minute operation.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then he inserts a needle with the laced string into the root of the eyelid, and makes it penetrate into the eyelid hastily, until he draws out the natural thread from above.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then pull the thread up to the level of the laced string: and insert into the same laced string that thread if it is one, two or three, not more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then pull your hand with it until the thread comes out of the laced string into the eyelid along with the natural thread.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	If however the thread is pulled out and the thread does not come out with it: pull the laced string downwards, along with the thread that you composed in it, until the laced string comes out from the upper part of the eye socket, and you see with your eyes: then only pull the laced string and the thread, and both (the laced string and the thread) remove them, and close the eyelid: and let it be closed for two days or three days, until the thread adheres to its place and grows over it on the skin.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the thread is short, then either tie it to a long thread from the natural hairs, and lift it up with it: or let it alone until it will stretch after some time, and then lift it up.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	The cure for Albuçâs' affliction that occurs on the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Head XIII.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this affliction occurs on the eye, it is called Leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this affliction of Albuçâs is either natural or acquired.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	An accident therefore occurs from the consolidation of a wound, or division, or cauterizing, and similar things.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the manner of operating on that is, as you can find this consolidation, and as you separate its parts, and put linen between them, and bind it, until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And it is not necessary to apply those things which burn and constrict them: for if you do that, Alxatrati's case will be worse than before: on the contrary, use those things which are mollifying, such as dried fodder: and apply a poultice with water in which cooked althea has been steeped, with flaxseed: and unguent of dy Aquaquin: which is liquid having been mixed with some of olive oil: and cover it with linen, and take care of it.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And the treasury of your cure is, that you will cut it with all your skill, so that it may not consolidate, according to its original shape.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And this operation which we mentioned is not but a correction of Alxatrati's case, so that it does not return to its original form entirely.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	¶ On the cure of Alxatrati which is performed on the lower eyelid, and it involves a wrinkling or tightening upward to the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XXIII.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This is what Alxatrati who occurs lower is truly called.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is a natural thing, and also an accidental one.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And the accidental one is formed from a wound, or a fracture, or a cauterization, and similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the manner of operating on it is, that you take a needle with two threads, and dye it in flesh, and make it penetrate from the inner lacrimal to the outer lacrimal, until the thread reaches both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then extend the flesh to the upper part with a knife, and cut it with a sharp scalpel.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If then the form of the eyelid returns according to what is fitting, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, take the radius, and put it in the fissure, and convert with it the eyelid: and find two fissures on the inner side of the eyelid, and they should be the extremities of the two incisions, until they meet and a corner is formed from them: until when they aggregate, let this figure be formed, and it is the Greek letter Lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then again take that flesh by the measure, which is the width of its sharp lower part, as it follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then gather together the separated parts: or that one with a thread of wool.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with what we said, concerning the soothing medicines and linens, until they are healed.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if there is an accident from the incision and suture or cautery on Alxatrati: then it is necessary to make a flat fissure under the hairs of the eyelid, even as before.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between two lips with a linen strip, according to what we said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the conclusion of the treatment for Alxatrati, when it is above or below, is that it should be cut in that operation, according to what has been prepared from the form of Alxatrati.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	Itself is also a variety of many differences in form: and the craftsman prudent prepares his skill with whatever way it is possible to him, until he forms again the figure towards the natural form, or near it, and himself the sick person, according to what suits him from the operation and instruments in various dispositions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	On the adherence of the eyelid with conjunctiva, or cornmeal.
Caput XV.	Head XV.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	In some cases this consolidation occurs in many people, so that the upper eyelid is concreted with the white of the eye, and prevents it from being subject to its natural operations.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Therefore you must insert the extremity of the radius under the eyelid, and lift it up: or extend it with a thread.
