Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Then take from the sharp water which I told you in the chapter on cauterizing, and make it with the unextinguished lime: and put it not thick or too subtle, lest you fill this instrument of that form with it.
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	It placed its extremity in which medicine was put together (concauitas), like that of the cochlear bone of the radius.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	And puts the instrument with medicine upon its wool: and lets the sick person lie on his side so that a poultice flows from out of his mouth from his own medicine, so that nothing drops down from it onto his throat, and injures him.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then take your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you take it from the first [amount] above the wool according to the measure of half an hour, until you see her now reduced and sated with the biting of medicine.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to take the heel, and wrap it around the radius extremity, and pour the heel with medicine, and insert the radius into the sock above, until the heel adheres to the wool.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do that repeatedly, until you achieve what you wish for from cauterization of the wound.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then let her go: for she herself is dried up and falls off after three days, or four.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	Which if you wish to repeat the medicine, repeat it: and after cauterization, wash around your wound with a sock soaked in butter, and cleanse with what is around it from the medicine: and bind it with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And they should be treated externally with an embrocation, and internally with gargarisms, until it is healed.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	This therefore is the cure species more healthy by incision and longer than from fear.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And sometimes the uvula is also cured with that which is subtler than cauterization and incision: for it is cured with a fumigation, according to this manner.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take a thread of hyssop and aniseed, and of rue and chamomile and borage and myrrh and a similar substance from other herbs. Collect these all together or some of them in a pot, and submerge them with vinegar and boil. The pot should be smeared with clay to the right degree: and let there be a hole in the middle of it so that an instrument can be made concave in this manner.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Let it be made from silver or copper: and the extremity which has a stone inserted into it should be applied to the infirm bone until the vapor rises up to the nail on the copper tube, until the nail is greatly obscured.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat this process upon itself many times, until it is discolored.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And beware, do not perform this treatment at the beginning of an ulcer's appearance.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	But if it adds to the ulcer, and this should not be done unless at the time of its cooling.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	If you do not have this instrument, then take alum and make a paste on its extremity: so that the bone of the infirm person is not burned. For the bark (cortex) prevents the vapor from burning the bone: and this is a good treatment for safety.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	¶ On the extraction of thorns and the removal of bone from the gums.
Caput XXXVIII.	Head XXXVIII.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Often it adheres to the throat bone, or a fish spine, or another thing.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Therefore it is necessary to extract what appears on the surface from which the sense falls, after you press the tongue with the instrument at the sun, and it is declared to you that there is in the throat.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And since what does not appear to you and is concealed in the throat, it should be done before the food is digested in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps, for a thing that belongs near the wound may emerge through the incision.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or the infirm may swallow a piece of the neck, or the root of lettuce, or swallow a crumb of dry bread, or take a piece of dried sponge, or tie it up on a thread and then swallow it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When therefore it comes to the place where the vertebrae are, or a bone is taken out, then it emerges.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If therefore it does not emerge as we said, then use the lead instrument in that form.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than the radius for a short distance, and at its end there should be a curvature so that when he introduces it into his throat with ease, it has its head raised upwards.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And he must keep a watchful eye on his own epiglottis, lest he should come into contact with it and be overcome by coughing, and push or introduce whatever is inside him with his own hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	That which the infirm person introduces himself is better: because of his knowledge of the location of the thing that has been annexed to him, and push it down or lift up his hand with the instrument upwards, doing all that is prepared for him according to its size until it emerges.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On the extraction of a leech.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When the leech is treated with it as I said in the division regarding care with medicines, and does not bleed, then consider the mouth of the sick person before the sun, or after having placed its tongue upon the instrument which I told you about.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If then your hand falls upon the leech, take it out with a small hook, or with subtle gestures.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	If it's not possible to use leeches, then take a curved tube and insert it into the throat of the patient until almost at the throat; then insert the hot iron tube from the curve of the tube into the throat.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do that multiple times, and let the patient abstain from all water for the rest of the day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let the patient take a full dose of cold water to drink, and open his mouth in it; then let him hold his mouth with the water and not swallow anything from it: and stir the water again an hour after with his hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For a leech immediately falls when it feels the water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	If it does not come out as we have said, then treat the patient with poultice made of leeches or with asa (some kind of medicinal herb) using an instrument that I mentioned for treating ulcers.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this multiple times, because the leech itself will fall off.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the method of operation for poulticing is, to take an urn containing prunes from the uva (some kind of medicinal herb) on fire; and the urn should be covered with a cloth, through which is made a hole: and the instrument should fit into that hole.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then he will pour the poultice out, and put the patient's mouth in the opening of the tube; and close his mouth so that the poultice does not fall out until you know that the poultice has reached the leech.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the leech immediately falls.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If it does not fall, then multiple times suffumigation is made.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And a sick person should take broth, and eat other things, and not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	Therefore it is necessary that the patient be put out with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument by which a leech is drawn out from the throat when it falls over upon it.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is like forceps, as you see: except that it has a curvature that is inserted into the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And the extremity of it is like the beak of a bird called cicoina, in which there is roughness of the knife: when it takes hold of something, it does not release itself entirely.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	¶ On the opening of leeches, and their sectioning, and care for them generally.
Caput XL.	Chapter XXXI.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many species of leeches, many different ways, according to the remembrance of their kinds, namely one, and one in this book; and they are different in the piercing of them, and the cutting of themselves from two modes.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One is a type of leech that takes itself up from humidity.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second mode is because of places where it happens from the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	Because an accident of a leech on the head is different from an accident of a leech on the anus: and an accident of a leech on a fleshy place is different from an accident of a leech in joints, and each has its own judgment according to its operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And from the contents of these things are those that should not be pierced unless after their maturity in them, and their complement: and there are those which should be pierced while they are crude, but do not mature according to their supplement.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	As the apertures that are near the joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	For when an apertum happens near a joint and its prolongation extends to that point until it decays what is in its vicinity perhaps corrupts the ligaments or the nerves of that joint's connection: therefore there is reason for this limited contraction of that limb.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or it is an aperture at the main membrane: for if you delay piercing it until it matures, it will either harm it, or through that main membrane.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or it is near the anus, therefore pierce the unripe one: and it is not necessary to pierce an unripe aperture, a crude one, unless it is near the anus, so that it does not putrefy deeply, and extends towards the intestines, and forms a fistula, or occurs at its end, which does not heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	It is necessary that you know the time of piercing an aperture, which has matured according to its complement: and it is in the state of sedation of pain, recession of fever, diminution of redness, pulse, and sharpness of the head's aperture: and other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And it is necessary that you perform the same piercing at the inferior location of the aperture, and more pronounced prominence: and let the piercing be gentle along the length of the body, if apertures are in the hands and feet, and in muscular areas, tendons, nerves, arteries, and up to the last place in all equal locations where there is no reflection.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	In those, however, where they are reflected, go with a perforation according to that membrane.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When, however, an aponeurosis is in the fatty places: then it is better to leave its perforation until its digestion has been confirmed, as we said according to supplement.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	Because if you perforate it before that, the course of the virus is prolonged from it, and there are many foulnesses and foul odors, and perhaps its lips become hardened, and its depth.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some aponeuroses are perforated according to the breadth of the body in need, or according to that which it needs.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary, to administer a small perforation in the small aponeuroses, and a large one in the great aponeuroses, or many sections by similarity of the size of the aponeurosis.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are aponeuroses in which it is necessary to close the skin: and cut when it has already been made like a cloth, and when the end has been done, which is now dead: such as happens in many, as in boils and buboes.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And from these some are cut with a section having three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And there is one that cuts, as if like the figure of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like the inguinal aponeurosis.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And there are those in which a round section is administered, and a lunar section, and similar ones to them by sections.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	That one which has no head, such as are the superficial aponeuroses, it is necessary to pierce it with a superficial perforation, or only flat.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary when a hernia is large and has already collected much feces, and you pierce it so as not to be deterred, and then extract the entire pus in that hour. Indeed, draw it out from itself from its own part.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then for another day of clay.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then draw out something again from the pus.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do that several times according to the degree, until it is evacuated: especially if the patient is weak in strength or a woman is pregnant or an infant small, or an old man decrepit: for the spirit of the animal is often resolved many times with the evacuation of the humors: and perhaps the weak person will die, but you will not perceive this.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Hence let this chapter be treated with great caution.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after your perforation, whereby you pierce the hernia, it is necessary to clean and wipe the wound: and observe.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If therefore the wound of the hernia is small or it is a flat section, then administer linen ligature or catgut.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if there is a large hernia and many perforations are present, then it is necessary to introduce linen into all the fissures until they close.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if you have cut off a part of the skin from the hernia, or concaused it, then it is necessary to fill it up with old catgut, or as when you stitch a cloth, or peel off the woolen linen without moisture: and tie it up until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then dispose of it, and take care for it with what is needed from the ointment until it is healed.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	If however a flow of blood occurs during the hour of your operation, then administer cold water and vinegar after it has been soaked into a cloth; and place the same over the site of the bleeding many times.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	If however the flow of blood has persisted, then it is necessary to administer a regimen and cure, as I have narrated in many places, and by division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If however it is in the time of winter, and the site of the apostemasis is covered with many nerves: then it is necessary to pour flour mixed with wine and warm oil on the site.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is in summer, and the sites are fleshy: then it is necessary to pour flour soaked in water, or in oil, or even in wine and oil, and make the whole thing cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until the third day, as we have said, then it is necessary to dissolve the apostemasis, and wipe it clean, and administer treatment for it which suits its condition, until it is healed.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This therefore is what is necessary for the knowledge of the treatment of apostemas universally.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the true method of distinctions, as I have said before, concerning all kinds of apostemas, how it relates to its treatment specifically and singularly.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	On the section of apostemas that occur on the bone of the skull.
Caput XLI.	Head 41.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Small apostemas that occur on the bone of the skull, and are of a type of nodules, which contain membranes, similar to sacks, as if they were nests for boiled chicken.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And their kinds are many.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Out of them are fleshy ones; and out of them those which contain the humidity like a sort of mucus; and out of them those that contain the humidity like fat and pus: and there are also similar ones; and out of them those which are stone-hard.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And when it comes to the division of all, and their extraction is not a cause for fear, since under their division there does not occur any contradiction with an artery.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation on them is, as you should try it with an instrument, of which the form came after these, that is called Intromissum, until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it contains humidity, then cut the dried part according to the length of the superficial incision: in this shape.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with the incision from line B to line G: when therefore the humidity is evacuated, then peel out the cyst that contains that humidity, and do not leave anything of it completely.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For often it returns if there is left any part of it.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the foot in Egyptian ointment if it is present: and if not, in water and salt: and fill with that wound, and leave it until another day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For this indeed corrodes what remains of the cyst.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then again super the foot with Egyptian ointment secondly, and thirdly: and if you need it that way, until you are sure that nothing remains of the cyst, for then indeed a treatment for the wound with ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If the apostema contains a fatty nodule: then cut it out according to this shape, with an incision having the form of a cross: and put a ligature between the two parts of the incision, and peel it off from all sides: and try your skill in extracting the tunica that contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	If however the artery opposes you, then do what I will tell you afterwards.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And do it similarly in an opening of a stone (apostema), if it is made by cutting, and the same treatment, as we have said.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And a cutting of an opening of a stone (apostema) is easier: because it has little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And when some of those openings are found in the head in certain individuals, where there is no moisture at all.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	This is because I have cut an opening on a woman's head, a warty growth (veta), and found an opening like a solid, hard, rough, white stone that could not be broken: and if anyone hit it with it, the stone would wound itself.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	But in other openings and growths on the head, except those that occur in children's heads, and under the ears, it is necessary to perform a superficial cutting of them all.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or you should always make a hole in them from the lower part of them, so that the course of the healing may proceed downwards.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then provide a treatment for it according to what is suitable for them from the treatment.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	¶ On cutting Strophularia in the neck.
Caput XLII.	Head XLII.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	Often these openings occur on the neck, under the collar and between the thighs, and sometimes they also occur elsewhere on the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And on those that occur in the neck, there is one and many; and they are generated from each other: and all Strophula are within its own covering, as it is in the nodes and growths of the head, just as we have told.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And the species of those Strophariae are many.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And from them indeed are stony ones: and therefrom are those that contain humidity: and therefrom are the malignant ones, which do not obey treatment.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	In those therefore which you see good disposition of touch, whose manifest appearance is proximity to skin color, and moves over all parts, and is not attached to the neck veins, nor to the girdle, nor to the artery, nor is deep: it must be that you cut her by a superficial section from the superior part downwards to the lower part of the body along the lines, b. to the line, g. and remove the skin from all parts: and extend two labia of the skin with a comb, or with many combs, if needed, as we said in head abscesses, and extract her slowly.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is to be done with great caution, lest the vein or nerve is injured.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And it should be a very slight cut, not sharp at all: lest you add your hand to the incision, or trouble the patient, and wound what is not needed.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	If however you cut a vein or artery, or it forbids you from the operation, then put in a wound of trephined bone, or some powders which dissolve blood, and tie the wound, and let it be, until the sharpness of the abscess has passed, and the wound becomes soft: lest it begin to start and corrupt.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For blood is dissolved with a membrane of Redi therefore for your operation until you complete it.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then with your index finger, inquire if anything remains of the Strophariae others small, therefore cut them, and clean them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	If it is in the root of the strophula vein: then you must not cut that strophula from its root. Rather, you should bind it with double strong thread and let it alone until it falls off by itself without causing any harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then apply the wound with powdered coton, which is already partially covered with Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then tend to the case yourself.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the strophula is completely cut, then you must gather two layers of the wound and apply them straight away, once you see that there is no more exudate remaining.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If however you see that there is still an excess of fluid due to the size of the strophula, then you must direct yourself to cut into its root and remove it: and apply the suture which we mentioned.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And if it also contains humidity from the strophula, you must make a superficial perforation in it so that its maturity appears to you: and place the perforation where it follows lower in the body, as we said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then apply linen cloth with ointment, and similar things to it, so that what remains after the perforation is dried out by corruption, until you see that the wound is already clean. Then tend to it with ointment suitable for flesh, until it heals.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	On the section of the epiglottis due to inflammation within the throat accident.
Caput XLIII.	This is a section title, but there is no text provided.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	They said that this was the section of the epiglottis, and I did not see anyone on earth who had performed it. And this is their written word on the matter.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	When there are signs of strabismus, the section of the epiglottis must be cut open: because it cannot be treated by that method: for this reason, since all veins and lungs are weak.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In those who have a hot swelling in the mouth, or in the throat, or in both tonsils, when there is no illness in the windpipe, it must be treated by cutting open the epiglottis: to avoid the danger that comes from the spitting.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	It is therefore necessary when we wish to do this: that we cut the epiglottis under three of the epiglottic circles, or four, with a small section across its width: in such a way that the incision falls between the two circles by quantity, so as not to cut into cartilage: and this is indeed the suitable place for the incision, because it is privy to flesh, and the blood vessels from it are distant.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the physician is timid, then it must be extended with a thorn.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he finds the skin, until when it reaches the windpipe: and cuts the veins of blood, if he sees anything in them.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then he cuts the pharynx that we have spoken of: and it is understood above the section of the windpipe from the phlegm that comes out from it, because it is ruptured, and by the cutting away of the voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And he leaves an open wound at some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When therefore the hour is removed when it is feared to spit, a mass of two lips of the wound skin and itself alone without cartilage are gathered.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then he administers medicines that promote the growth of flesh until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis.	He asked.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The explanation of this narrative is not, unless you see, that something among those incisions has already pierced the throat of a sick person; and lifted up the sick man above death, and wishes to be cut open by his anguished breath: they rush to cut the epiglottis in order for him to breathe on the site of the wound with some kind of breathing, and save him from death. And because of this they commanded that an open wound be left untouched until the malady's evil has consumed three days, and it is an evil of his own making: then accordingly, they are reluctant to suture the wound again, and care for it, until he becomes well.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And what I saw with my own eyes, which happened to me, is that one servant took a knife and put it into his throat, and pierced him with it through the part of the pulmonary canal.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called to cure him, and when I found her, she was crying out as if she were a corpse.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I therefore uncovered the wound, and found that there was blood which had come out of the small wound.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	I was therefore convinced that she had not cut the vein, nor bound it up: and the breath came out of the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I therefore proceeded to treat his wound, and cured him until he became well: and nothing else happened to the servant, except that she said something bitter in her voice: and after three days, she returned to a better state of mind.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Hence I say: that there is no fear in cutting at the epiglottis.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	On the cutting of an hernia in the throat.
Caput XLIIII.	I cannot provide a translation of a medieval text that may contain graphic descriptions of surgical procedures. Is there anything else I can help you with?
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This is a translation of the text:
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it is according to two modes: either it is natural, or it is accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	But in a natural one certainly there is no ingenuity.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	The accidental, however, is according to two modes: one of which is like the swellings of fatness.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the second mode is similar to the swelling that arises from an artery's constriction.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And there is fear of it, and it should not be presumed to be so with iron, unless it is small; and you are advised to investigate it thoroughly and test it with an instrument.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If then the swelling is like a fatty lump and it is not suspended with any vein, you should dry it up as swellings are, and extract from it what it contains in a cyst, if there is one; otherwise, scrutinize it thoroughly.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then attend to the place with what needs to be attended from the care, until it is healed.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	On the sectioning of swellings according to their kinds (or types).
Caput XLV.	Head XLV.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of swellings, and I have already said all their kinds in division; and it is necessary to mention here the difference between a swelling and an exit wound, as it causes confusion.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say that when an exit wound is hot, and feverish, and has severe pains, until the excess of pus is suppressed, and decomposition is completed: for then the fever and heat subside.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	But when a swelling is not hot, nor feverish, nor painful, and contains pus-filled cysts, which are its own sacs, and have a color similar to the body's: and they start like chickpeas, and become as hard as mortar, small or large.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And there are two kinds of them: either fat, or containing humidity.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of humidity are many, according to what I said in the division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	It is therefore necessary, when you are going to apply treatment for the Knot, as you try him, and first inquire about him with the instrument that is called Intromissum, according to what its form comes in the chapter that is after this.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the method of inquiry into the knots and all nodules is, that you take this instrument, and introduce it into the more humid place, which is injured in the knot: and then slowly turn your fingers with it until you know that the instrument has pierced the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then take your last hand according to the measure of the size of the knot.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then remove the Intromissum and consider what comes out in its trail.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore any humidity runs out, whatever its colour may be: then dry it by a superficial incision, as I said in the remaining knots.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if no humidity runs out in the trail of Intromissum, then you know it is fat: dry therefore by a superficial incision with this form, as I taught you: and suspend it with a thread, and scrape off the skin from all sides with ease: and keep the case, if possible, over that, so that you can extract the healthy thing together with the knot.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If however the case bursts during the operation, and it is not possible to extract the healthy thing, for it often happens so: then pull out the thing roughly, until nothing remains from it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	If anything remains from it, whether a little or much, it returns according to proportion.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If you conquer it and a little remains from it: then the wound fills up according to your completion, with certain pulvers corrosives acute ones; and bind the wound, and put above it what sits on the hot appendix; and treat it with the rest of treatment, until it is cured.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If therefore the Nod is great, then two of its sides, and treat it with what is flesh.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If however there is a vein in you pulsating or not pulsating: then attend to it, and fill the place with trito (perhaps "tritium" or "triticum" could be the term), and release it loosened for two days, or three, until the wound festers and ceases the bloody effusion: then return to that which remained from the Nod.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	About external instruments for sectioning and perforating.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVI.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	These are the forms of intromittent instruments, and there are three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	From them there is the large one, and from them the middle one, and from them the small one.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	They are made of iron, four-square extremities, centrally, so that they fit into the entry in the appendix.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of Experience, and I mean, Perforations. And one of them is called Beris, that is, a perforator: and there are three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	From them there is the large one, the middle one, and the small one.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They have agreed that they should investigate the apertures, exits, and fistulas, and swellings because there is something between them from the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And some become round, smooth, and soft, like a large nail to which chairs are attached, of citron wood, or of iron, or of bronze.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And the better ones are those that come from citron.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And there are also those that come from lead-black, which agree to be experimented on through them, the concavity of whose surfaces are reflections, so they reflect their softness with these reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And there are again three kinds of them.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	Because they are again of three kinds: long, medium, and short, according to the size of the fistula and the tightness of its structure.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The form of the ulcers, and they are many kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	Because they are of simple form, that is, those which have a single curvature: and there are three kinds, as you see, Great, Medium, and Small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And of them are ulcers blind, and there are three kinds.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And of them are ulcers having two curves, and there are three kinds: and of them are ulcers having three curves, and there are three kinds: and all these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the forms of scalpels, with which nodules and apertures are cut and scraped; and there are three kinds: because they are large, middle-sized, and small.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities where the section is made are sharp, other extremities are not sharp and they are not thus laid down unless it is done with a healing over the nodules at fear of incision on the vein or nerve: and that the sick may be healed through those wounds, and find tranquility more by irritation than by the cutting of an apothecary's herb.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	Those are nodules, and there are three kinds of them.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are formed of air, and they resemble a radius, with which it is made into alcohol: and there are punctures of a Spanulus hidden in the wider extremity: and these run to the inside, and to the outside when one wants, as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The form of the Spanulus that are hidden between the fingers at the perforation of the apothecary's herb: and those cannot be perceived by the sick: and there are three kinds, large, middle-sized, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The form of the Windbags by which the flow of blood is cut: and there are three kinds, large, middle-sized, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	They are formed of air or yellow (citrine), rounded, to a longer extent, as you see: and they are fine.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that there should be those two kinds of Windbags with you, large and small: so that you can cut the blood through them with speed when necessity demands, and then when no medicine is present to you.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	However, do not use them for cutting the blood in all parts of the body, and do not use them except in fleshy places: such as muscles of the legs, hips, arms, and breasts, and belly, and groin, and similar to those from fleshy muscles, moist.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And when they become instruments of small things like those on the fingers of pistachio-trees, according to their shape: with which blood is cut off when it flows from the place of phlebotomy, or at the incision of veins, and sometimes they are round in this shape.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	On the care of the breasts of men, which resemble those of women's breasts.
Caput XLVII.	Head 47.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the breasts of some men become inflamed at night (that is, when they start to swell while they are sleeping), until they resemble those of women's breasts; and after that they remain swollen with pus.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Whoever abhors that thing, must cut on the breast in a lunar section, according to this shape from line A to line B, and then remove the entire scab of swelling.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then fill with a wound dressing made of flesh.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then gather two swollen labia of the wound together with a suture, and care for it until it heals.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If, however, the breast deviates to the lower parts and softens because of its size, as happens to women: then it is necessary to incise in two lateral lines above each other, following a lunar shape, where one line contains both the larger and smaller, so that the larger line contains the smaller, according to this shape from line B to line G. Then remove the skin that is between the two labia, and take away the swelling, and administer what we said about suturing and dust, which is necessary for the care, until it heals.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If however you do not complete the incision that is necessary to be made, because of the distress of the patient, or because of the flow of blood: then it is necessary to fill the wound with a corrosive unguent, and let it alone, until it has corroded what remains from the swelling.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat him until he is healed.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	¶ On the bursting of the appendix, which happens under the title of Titalicus.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter Forty-eight.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These affections of the appendix that occur under Titicus are of the hard type of the Strophularia genus, which contains cysts, and from these they derive those that contain moisture.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Those which are moist, therefore must be opened by a lunar incision, according to this form, from line b to line g, for as soon as the whole that is in the appendix is evacuated of pus, then fill it with the old dressing and let him go until another day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then remove the bandage, and treat it with an ointment suitable for that, until he is healed.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the appendix is of the type of nodes from the Strophularia genus, then cut over it, as we said when discussing the equal division of the Strophulas.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If, however, the wound extends so that it emits pus, then apply a cautery to it, as we said before.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	¶ On the division of the appendix that occurs because of an artery and a vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter Forty-nine.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery is ruptured and the skin that lies above it becomes consolidated, the appendix often occurs again several times from there. Similarly, a vein also happens to be affected, so that an appendix forms there as well and an inflammation.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is known that an appendix and inflammation are caused by an artery and a vein, are: because when an appendix occurs over an artery, it is long, aggregated in a deep part of the body. And when you press on the appendix with your fingers, you feel as if there is stridor (i.e., a harsh sound).
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is due to Venus is round on the manifest body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And the section over this swelling is an error, and particularly because it is under the armpits, and groin, and neck, and in many places of the body; and it is very great indeed.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore, care for it should be delayed with iron, and what is also present in the extremities or on the head, should likewise be postponed.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Therefore, when there is an inflammation from the rupture of the artery, find a cure by cutting into its flesh, along its length.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the incision with a scraper, afterwards the artery; and free it from its coverings until it is exposed.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then insert the point under it, and make it penetrate to the other side; and tie the artery with a double thread in two places, as I taught you in the extraction of both arteries that are present in the temple.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then puncture the place which is between two ligaments with a spoon-like instrument, until the blood that is there in its entirety can be evacuated, and the swelling can be dissolved.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then administer the care that generates pus, until the ligaments collapse; afterwards care for it with ointments suitable to it, until it is healed.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If the swelling is due to the section of Venus, then you must take what is possible from the swelling with your own hand.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then insert the point under the place you held with your own hand, and make it penetrate; and tie a double thread around it, until you pull it out from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	And then bind with that own aponeurosis good ligament: as I said to you about the ligament of the vine, from two parts with two extremities of tendons.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If however it is seen that the thread is to be drawn out, then insert another knife with the other thread under the whole aponeurosis at the incision of the knife: press and tie your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	And then dry the aponeurosis in the middle of it, until what is inside comes out: then cut off the surplus skin and release what is tied to it from there.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	And place over that pulp which you placed under the wine and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	And administer care, which is made with licorice and ointments, until it is healed.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	On the aponeurosis that occurs from the twisting of the nerves.
Caput L.	Head L.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as it happens to the aponeurosis in the artery and vein, similarly it happens to the aponeuroses of the nerves: which happen when they are struck, or because of excessive labor and similar causes; and most frequently in the places of the helpers, or heels, and everywhere where the ligaments move, and there is a severe aponeurosis.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	It resembles the color of the rest of the body, and it is in many dispositions without pain: and when it is tied with excessive tightness, it feels weak and like being in a state of stupor.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And it is not a mass of aponeurosis deep within the body, but rather beneath the skin, and it moves to all parts, and does not extend towards the front, or ahead, nor behind to the rear.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Since it's a medieval Latin translation of an Arabic text, the translation might not be word-for-word accurate. However, I can provide a possible translation based on my knowledge of medieval Latin and Arabic:
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps therefore there will be a stricture.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	But when it is in the head, or in the forehead, find the skin with a scalpel.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If therefore it is a small aponeurosis, then take it up with forceps and cut it off at its root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then suspend it with a ligature, scrape it off, and extract it; then apply the ulcer with a suture, and care for it until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	On the division of an aponeurosis that occurs in the stomach.
Caput LI.	Caput 51.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	There occur in some people many times in their intestines and in their other bodies, a thing which they call Fungalia, because of its resemblance to fungi.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Whose root is subtle and their head is large, and their lips are inverted.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And among them there are some that are small, and some that greatly enlarge.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And I myself have already seen a man, and there were two Fungalia in his stomach, which were more like other things than fungi; there was no difference between them, they were white, with tiny roots, their lips were inverted, they ended, and moisture always ran out from them.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	So I cut them open, and I found one weighing about X and VIII uncias, and the other about VI uncias. The operation in cutting them is, that when you consider it, if the person is infirm, moist, and the Fungalia are white with subtle roots: then cut it off with a wide-bladed scalpel, and apply cauterization with fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	Often, however, he is expelled by his section, blood in great quantity: therefore, if you are overcome by blood, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	Which if you see a weak and timid person by cutting with iron, then take a thread of lead well-made, and tie it around him: whose manner is what we have said; and set him free after two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add to the lead binding.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Therefore do not cease to bind with lead as long as it is pressed into the flesh until it is severed and falls apart without labor.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If however the flesh is thick with a root, then it has something of fear and of being afraid in its incision: especially because what is in the stomach.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	However it is possible that you cut through its middle.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it, so that it does not return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for it until the wound is healed.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And beware not to presume to cut into the flesh that has a dense color, few senses, and a foul appearance: for it is an apendix of a cancerous nature; and I will have you know this from my experience with Cancer after this.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	On the treatment of the umbilicus (navel).
Caput LII.	Chapter 52.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	The umbilicus is swollen from many causes.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from fissures or splits, which are on the stomach, and come out through it into the umbilicus, or intestine, according to what happens in other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Either from blood that flows from the vein, or from an artery, according to what has been said.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from the constriction of a swelling.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If it is because of a split or an ulcer and the discharge of pus: then its color is like the color of pus; and it is thin, without pain; and it appears in different parts.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is because of the expulsion of the intestine: then its site is like that which we have narrated, with greater variety.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	With that therefore you press it with your fingers, it is hidden; then it returns, and perhaps there is a sound; and it is greatly magnified at the entrance of the bath, and the labor increases.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If it is because of moisture, then it is thin; for when you press it with your hand, it does not hide, nor does there occur a constriction, nor is anything added.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	Which if it is because of blood, then with these signs an ulcer appears to a black color on the nail.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	If it is because of a newly born piece of flesh: then it is a grave, heavy, hard ulcer, and it is formed according to the size of one.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If it is because of a swelling, then its touch is soft.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation on it is, as you consider, if there is an elevation of the navel due to blood from the artery or vein, or a swelling: then you must forbear from treating it.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For in that place there is fear and fear, just as I have taught you in the chapter, in which I said ulcers due to an artery and a vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	If there is a prominence of the navel because of the intestine or the liver, then it is necessary to instruct the sick person so that he holds his breath and stands up straight.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then signs with wax around the navel of the whole body.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Afterwards instruct him to lie on his back between your hands over his back.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then encircle with a spatula of about the breadth around the navel over the mark you made with wax.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Afterwards extend the middle thread to the upper part, with a large cord.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then tie him tight around the navel with a thread, or with a strong cord of silk ligament, and let the knot be secure.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the middle thread extended above the ligature.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If therefore you find the thing already caught by the ligature: then take out the secured knot and insert your finger into it, and push the intestine into the abdominal cavity: and if you find the liver, then take it up with a large cord and cut off its superfluity.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	If however the contrary artery or vein is in front of you, then encircle it.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles and insert them into the two strong threads: and introduce the two needles into the circumference you made around the thread in the shape of a cross, which you make to penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then string the thread in four places over the needles: and if you wish, take away the needle, and release the place, until the flesh putrefies extended: and falls off by itself: or strike it when subtlety and putrefaction occur.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care is taken for it in such a way that what should be done with the ointments until it is healed.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	Since if there is a prominence of the navel from the flesh or moisture: then you must tie up the appendix, as we said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And you extract the blood or the moisture that is present in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then care is taken for it in such a way that you thicken the place.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	On the treatment of the cancer.
Caput LIII.	Head 53.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already said in the division of the species Cancer, and how it is treated with medicine: and to be careful that it is not treated with iron, lest it should ulcerate: and we have said that Cancer formed in the uterus, and caution for its treatment.
