Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I restored her therefore and the wound was consolidated, and she was cured with intact health, and nothing harmed her.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I will tell you the quality of extracting some arrows: so put that rule and definition over what I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Because the parts of this art and their distinctions do not encompass the narrative: neither does this book comprehend it, and a prudent craftsman compares with little against much: and since what is near, over that which is absent: and he invented a new operation, and a new instrument in the descent of things extraneous to this art when they happen.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore that arrows do not emerge from limbs that are fixed, except in two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by attraction from the place where it entered within.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or through the opposite side of another limb.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And those which emerge from where it entered are either a projectile proceeding into the flesh, and attracted and emerges.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	Which if it does not obey to exit from the hour when it falls: then you must let it alone for a few days, until the flesh around it has putrefied, and its attraction is loosened, and its exit.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if it is embedded in a bone, and you do not obey its exit: then let it alone for another few days: and carry it with attraction and movement every day, until it emerges.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	Which if it does not obey your exit after a few days: then you must perforate the surrounding area of the arrow in the bone itself from all sides with a sharp trephine, until the arrow is expanded.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then attract her, and extricate herself.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	But if the arrow is fixed in the bone of the skull and has already proceeded into one part of the brain, and it appears that some of their other injuries are as I said: then refrain from drawing back the arrow, and let her be left alone until she becomes equal to herself after a few days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow reaches the pharynx, then death is not prolonged to her.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed only in the bone and does not penetrate to the pharynx: but it remains weak for a few days, and no further injury befalls her from those injuries: then use your ingenuity in drawing back the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	But if it is fixed very firmly and does not obey you to be drawn back: then administer a powder of breadcrumbs around the arrow, as I have narrated to you: and then care for the place until she heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If the arrow is already hidden in the body, and concealed and concealed from sight: then search for it with probes.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel her, then draw her back with some instruments that are suitable for drawing her.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If you are unable to draw her back, because of the constriction of the wound and due to the length of the arrow in deep: and there is no bone, nor a tendon, nor a vein: then strike above her, until the wound becomes more enlarged, and it will be possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	But if she has ears that need to be bound: then free the fixed flesh from them in all parts, by all means you can do it, and ingeniousness, if you cannot get her escape from the fracture of the ears and their twisting until it escapes.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you administer an extraction of the arrow, in any place it may be found, then use your hand's contortion with bowstrings to all parts, until you make it escape; and with subtlety, the last subtlety, so that the arrow does not break, and its extraction will be difficult for you, and for itself.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you cannot remove it from her in one hour, then release her for a few days, until the things around her have decayed.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat this process: for she will be cleansed if the wound is covered with a tunic. But if it causes an opposite reaction, then administer what we said in our cure in its chapter; and keep your virtue from the incision of the vein, or nerve, or cord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer your ingenuity in all the way possible to escape the arrow; and let it be with facility, calmness, or slowness, and firmness, as I have told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary that, when you pull the arrow out, the patient be laid according to their form, as they were at the time of the arrow's fall.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Because it is more advantageous.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If it is not possible for you to do that, then administer what is possible from the patient's form.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	However, the arrow that comes out from the opposite part of another limb, or has already proceeded from it something to the outside, or makes swelling at the extremities of the arrow through the sense from the upper part of the skin nearby, and you see it protruding: then cut off over it, and let the section be according to the size that they grasp in it with their feet.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then pull her out: for she is made easy to exit.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If it is retained in the bone, then twist your hand according to its circular shape until the arrow strikes into the bone, and amplify yourself; then pull it.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: let it go for a few days; then repeat it, until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	Which if the wood of the arrow is in it, then push it with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If the wood has fallen and you wish to apply a push: then insert into it a curved instrument, so that its concavity enters into the arrow shaft: then push it with itself.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If the arrow is concave, then push it with the instrument inserted into itself.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	For the arrow is purified through that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	Which if the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary, that you crush the entire flesh into which the poison is, if it can be done for you.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then treat her with what is suitable to that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	Which if the arrow is falling into the chest, or stomach, or eye, or side: and it is near that you touch with the lancet, and it can be possible for you to cut over her: then dry, and beware of the incision from the poison, or nerve, and remove her.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wound, if you see it, and care for that until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of the Forcipium, by means of which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	Let there be extremities similar to the beak of a bird, which are made like iron: when they take hold of the arrow, do not let them go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And many kinds of shapes are made from them, great and small, and middle-sized, according to the size of the arrowhead, its slenderness, the width of the wound, and the tightening of it.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The shape that drives forward is concave.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the driving-forward shape is obtuse.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the obtuse extremity like a radius, so that its entrance into the concave arrowhead may be made to match it, and driven along with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	Its obtuse extremity is concave like the beak of a bird: so that its entrance into the arrowhead may be made to match it, and with it.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On the venous phlebotomy.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter 97.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The venous phlebotomy veins, whose custom runs in the body, are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	From these there are sixty: six pulsatile veins, which are behind the ears and are called two Herbs; and two arteries that appear in two temporal regions; and two veins that appear in the two lacrimal sacs of both eyes, which are called Aspicientes; and a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead; and a vein that is at the extremity of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two Guideg veins, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins that are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins that are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are called Algecherich veins.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	Veins which are cut for phlebotomy on the arms, there are five veins in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is called the Cephalic vein and it comes from the outer side of the forest: and it is also commonly known as the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And the Dark or Black vein.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And there is the Median vein, and it is composed of a branch of the Basilic vein, and a branch of the Cephalic vein: and it is also commonly known as the vein of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilic vein, and it is placed on the inner side of the house: and it is also commonly known as the Titlecar vein.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And it is also commonly known as the vein of the abdomen.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the vein of the arm, and it is placed over the elbow: and it is that from which one cuts blood, and it is that which appears above the wrist with a clear and evident pulse.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the Salutaellar vein, and it is a vein which is between the ring finger and the little finger: and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And there are three veins in the leg.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is which is under the thumb, cut from the outer side of the forest.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is the Saphenous vein, and its location is near the heel, on the inner side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And there is also a vein called Nessus, and its location is near the heel, on the outer side of the forest.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And on the other leg there are three veins similar to those.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	On the bloodletting of both legs after the Ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The bloodletting of both legs that are after the Ears, is an antidote to old coughs, and a hemigranite, and sahafta, and a severe head ulcer.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of bloodletting in that is because I will say.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is, that the head of the sick person be scraped: and his occipital region be rubbed with a rough cloth at the place of both legs.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then tie the sick person's neck with a bandage, until two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And the places of these are after the Ears in two depressed places of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Search therefore with your finger, and where you feel a pulse of their ear with your finger, there mark the signs with wax.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take a bloodletting knife, and that is he who is called Incisus.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert the knife into the vein under the skin, until the bloodletting reaches the bone.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then lift your hand with the vein and skin upwards, and cut the vein with a skin incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be the quantity of two interlocked fingers, or about that: and make it go out as much as possible from blood.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then tie her with wool, and let her go, until she is healed.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And now precedes the cutting of their ears at the beginning of the book, and their own cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	On the removal of blood from two arteries at the right time.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	Indeed the two arteries that are used for the treatment of these three diseases - haemorrhagia ancient, glaucoma bad and frequent, and excessive bleeding - are in two places: one in the groin region and another near the eye.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of the blood to be drawn from them is as I am going to tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	He should tie the neck tightly, until the two veins appear by their apparent appearance and it is demonstrated that the pulse of both under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then signs with wax.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then take the skin above the vein with your index finger and introduce the venesection under it, then lift the vein again above.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut her as you have done on the other two veins, and make a flow from the blood according to the need of your treatment.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then loosen the tie of the patient and place your finger on top of the vein.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then place your hand over that skin and the poultice, and tie it tight with a strong constraint above; and release it until it is cured.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And now the previous mention of them, and their cutting, and extraction at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	On the bloodletting of the forehead vein after cephalic bloodletting.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The treatment for the bloodletting of the forehead vein is after cephalic bloodletting, to treat old facial ailments and hemorrhages, and painful redness, and foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of his phlebotomy is this, as I am going to tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	He binds the swollen neck with a bandage until it appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take up the instrument which is called Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	Whose this form is.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Put the sharp point that is at the top of the Fossorium head over this vein and strike on it with a scalpel or with some other instrument according to its manner, and let the blood flow out in proportion as you wish.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then dissolve the perforation of the swollen one and bind it again until it is healed.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And when it opens up with the phlebotomist's side.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it is not necessary that there should be a phlebotomy of the sharp extremity, as was the case with the previous phlebotomies, but rather of the broad extremity.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And the phlebotomy through the turning: because the bone is close, and perhaps the phlebotomy may be broken when it is thin.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	On the venous phlebotomy in two lacrimal ducts.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The instrument for the two venous phlebotomies which are in the two lacrimal ducts of two eyes is to be applied to the eye from scabs and redness: and to apply to the eye, and to alleviate facial pains.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of their phlebotomy is that he should bind the swollen neck with a bandage.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then perform the venous phlebotomies on them, and you are standing over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	Let it be that there should be a small phlebotomy according to the length backwards, with a small leech, a larger one, because in that place there is no fat.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	For if the leech is subtle of the extremity, it may be broken.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then do run with the blood as much as there is need to you.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And put them on your back, and tie them tight at night, and release them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	On phlebotomy of the nasal veins.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The veins of the nose for phlebotomy, is associated with acute fever and severe coughing, and facial distress, such as hemigranema, and redness that occurs on the face: especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of his phlebotomy is, that he strings his weak neck tight.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	And then take his nose with your left hand, and receive a small leech, long, and put it on the middle of the rabbit of his own, between that which separates the nose according to the straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Because the vein does not appear to the sense there, and because the blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary, that with the large leech, you put your hand, and make the blood run according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then tie her up at night one.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For she is restored quickly.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	On phlebotomy of the veins of the Groin.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	The true guide to phlebotomy is that of constriction by breathing in, and the beginning of leprosy, and melancholy pains, and petechiae, and bad ulcers, and corrosive ones, namely, those caused by itchy herpetical skin.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of their phlebotomy is that it ties up the weak under both arms with a bandage: and the artisan stands over the head of the sick person, and the sick person sits on a chair.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then the bandage becomes longer after the length of the bandage has been stretched out a little.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then take out from the blood a moderate quantity, or according to what you see necessary for it.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do similarly with another vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Afterwards loosen the bandage, and tie two veins with a medium-sized bandage so that it does not constrict the sick person.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let him go until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	For the wound is healed.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	¶ On the venepuncture of Albucasis.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The veins of Albuqasis are a remedy for phlebotomy: because it carries away the acid from the mouth and corruption of the gums; bad ulcers; fissures of the lips; bad ulcers; and even those that are in the nose, and around its vicinity.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of their phlebotomy is that you should make the sick person sit in front of you, and tie his neck with a bandage.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then roll back his lip, and look at the two veins: one from the right side of the lip, and the other from the left side of it; and show both by the blackening of the gums.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And it is true that because of their curvature, they have fine, black veins.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Cut therefore into both with the cutting incision itself.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If there is doubt about you, and you do not know what they are: then attend to the greater of their incisions, and their more obvious one.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And so do the same for both veins that are in the upper lip: and there is a great custom with it; and cut two veins that are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	On phlebotomy of the vein under the tongue after cephalic phlebotomy.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	The treatment of the two veins that are under the tongue is this: that the cephalic phlebotomy is for the afflictions that are in the throat, and the illness of the tongue, and the ailments of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is this: that the sick person should sit between your hands in front of the sun: and uncover his tongue, and look at one vein under the side of his tongue, and another under the other side: and if the color of both turns to blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	So perform both the phlebotomy: and keep watch, lest you put your final hand into it.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	Because under them are arteries, and perhaps there may occur a flow of blood from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	On the three veins in the elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The three veins that are cut in the elbow, which is a common phlebotomy for all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And phlebotomy of their ears is done in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Or by pricking with myrtle of large leaves: or by oiling to a subtle decline: or cutting with the surgeon's knife, and it is called Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is, that is convenient for incision.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from them are the types broad and subtle according to the length of the veins and their constriction. The form of phlebotomy with myrtle is broad, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is convenient for opening the curved veins that are swollen, full, and those that proceed, appear, and are coarse, those which contain thick, turbid blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this phlebotomy is of lesser width and subtlety at the extremities.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is convenient for the phlebotomy of the subtle veins that contain fine, yellowish blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	Of the Phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	But those that are one of the three members of the phlebotomy of the basilica.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws out the blood from the afflictions that are under the neck and throat, following the chest and abdomen: and it is convenient for the phlebotomist to have a phlebotomy of this kind, so as to beware, because there is an artery under it.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore he erred and added to the wound of the phlebotomy, he would hit that artery, and there would be a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is necessary that he not be pierced with a knife by the phlebotomist with the sharp instrument: but let him be cut with Alnasil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	For if the basilica does not appear in a clear and visible way, then it is necessary that you look for another of its kind, or change to another one, or seek out some part of it: or let the phlebotomist take its place with the cord of the arm.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For it is itself evident and dry with the phlebotomist Alnasil, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If however you wish to perform the operation of his own, then it is necessary to touch the place before the stricture of the arm, until you know the location of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the spot with wax afterwards the arm, and cut the vein in a concave section with the phlebotomist Alnasil, as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And beware lest the percussion fall through the space to the location of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see, with you tying the ligament, that there is an inflation at the place which you marked with wax, then that inflammation is of the artery: therefore remove it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If you see blood slipping at the operation of the phlebotomist, like a child's urine, and it is red, thin blood: then know that it is from the artery.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then therefore be quick, and put your finger on the same place with a long space, then withdraw your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If however the blood is cut (and it is often cut), then tie the arm and release it: and beware the sick person from its movement: and let him be above its fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And he did not stir for some days, until he was healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	But if the blood is not cut away, and you are conquered by it: and there is no remedy for you in that moment, then strike the artery, if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For his extremities are contracted and the blood is cut.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take the skin of a pig, and cut it; take half of it, and bind it over the wound with a suitable stricture, fastened by a bandage and dust until the next day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if the blood is cut away, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not, then the treatment is for him whom the previous one has remembered, from the place of the powder of the cutting blood flow: and the cutting away of his blood is not difficult in many dispositions, due to the smallness of the wound's location, and the possibility of a ligature from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	On cutting the black vein (phlebotomy).
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	But the black vein (phlebotomy) is its remedy, that draws blood from the upper part of the head, and the lower body: because it is composed of the Basilic branch and the Cephalic branch, as we said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is fitting for the person performing the phlebotomy to make it so that there is a fear of being cut by his phlebotomy, because under him is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	So if therefore the phlebotomy is added to the wound (puncture), and he finds a nerve, then occurs in that a paralysis, and it becomes difficult for his healing, and perhaps he will not be healed at all.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve is often apparent to the sense.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	But if it is hidden in some people, and is subtle, and does not appear: then you must use your own phlebotomy, which is the removal of phlebotomata or a section with Al-Nesil, and carefully cut the nerve with your own strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If a vein is between two nerves, then find the vein along its length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	About the Cephalic vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	The remedy for the phlebotomy of the Cephalic vein is, because it attracts blood from the head and conveys to the sufferings of the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is necessary in this vein itself, if you wish, to perform the phlebotomy by piercing it with olive oil phlebotomy or myrtle phlebotomy: because it is more salubrious than all veins, for it is neither under an artery nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	But it is more convenient for you to apply the technique of phlebotomy by carefully piercing only the skin over the head, and searching for a softer spot: and it will not harm him if he is not injured with the first stroke, as long as you repeat the procedure several times on top of it.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	But perhaps it may happen to some people that when not treated with a first stroke of phlebotomy, the formation of a nodule occurs; but it will not do him any harm.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	About the utility of phlebotomy and the precautions to be observed in its performance.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of phlebotomy and the accidents that occur from it, about which you should consider adjusting.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Firstly it is necessary to know that phlebotomy cannot be administered except for the preservation of health and its persistence, and caution against the arrival of sickness.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And so phlebotomy should be performed on one of the three veins that are located in the cubital area, namely the cephalic vein, the fusca vein, and the basilica vein.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And so phlebotomy should be performed at the beginning of spring, during fasting, in truth, and summer; and autumn, and winter after eating, when signs of depletion appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And phlebotomy should be performed on the first day, or on the third day, after they have completed three days of fasting.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Phlebotomy that is administered during illnesses does not have a fixed hour; but when it is convenient and necessary, to do so, at night, or day, or any time, and at any season.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not necessary that children should undergo phlebotomy until they are fourteen years old.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	A pregnant woman should not undergo phlebotomy except from the fourth month to the seventh.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Aged individuals who have already surpassed sixty years should not undergo phlebotomy.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When therefore anyone wishes to undergo phlebotomy for any reason whatsoever, it is necessary that he purify his bowels beforehand with a gentle laxative, if there is much retained stool in them: so as not to attract veins to the phlebotomy due to superfluous and putrid waste from the intestines, which can be harmful to the main body members.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	A person who is undergoing a cut or wound, that is, has inflammation or nausea from overeating, should not undergo phlebotomy; nor should an intoxicated person, nor one who is recovering from drunkenness, until he has been removed from it.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	And not weak with hydrophobia.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let phlebotomy be done again after a colic attack, and vomiting, and intestinal flow, and multiplication of coitus, labor, exercise, and watchfulness, and fasting, and all that dissolves the power from the body or animal.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider the subtlety of the humors before that, if the blood is thick with food and drink, and medicines: if it can be done.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then let the bath in, if nothing is prohibited by it: or exercise itself with some exercise, so that the blood may be subtle.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And place the phlebotomy in his chest, on the third day, as we said: and try to that he may be emptied of his chest on that day from all animal evils such as straitness, anger, and fear: and from all bodily accidents such as labor, punishment, and overindulgence, and like things.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let him have those things present which are used by the custom of men from their fragrance and scent, and noise, and similar things, in proportion to the possibilities.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then has the phlebotomist sit over the pulvinar, which be higher than the pulvinar of the phlebotomy: afterwards he takes out his arm, and rubs it with his own hand twice, or thrice.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then he wraps the ligature around the corrigia and folds it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And the binding should be moderate, for a strict binding when it is unequal, or due to excessive tightness in binding, it then prevents the flow of blood; or in softening, it also prevents the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after tightening, it is necessary to have the phlebotomist rub his hands together in order that the veins may be inflamed, and they may reveal their state by sensation.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomist wipes off the wounds of the phlebotomized with a little oil, an old-fashioned way.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he places his finger on the index of the left hand over that vein under the spot where he wants to perform the phlebotomy, a little: so that the vein does not flee away, and there be a percussion.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Because from veins comes what flees to the vein as if fleeing along a string with the phlebotomy: and from them is that which is full of airiness; and when you put the phlebotomist on it, it contracts under the phlebotomist, and deceives the phlebotomator, and does not open the vein, or if it opens, it is tightly closed: therefore it is necessary for the phlebotomator to be firm, and to be careful about these things in all respects.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he removes the phlebotomist.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If therefore the vein opens from one puncture, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then iterate that puncture again under the same spot a little, or above it with some persistence: if the spot will not yield.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	If the spot yields or softens the weak one, then let him depart for a day, or two days: and do not tie the bandage.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps because an inflamed spot might be attracted to it.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	And do not enter the bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then repeat the phlebotomy if he desires.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the opening is small or there runs a little blood: and you fear that it should flow out of the blood amount equal to the strength: then perform phlebotomy repeatedly in the same vein according to its direction, and add a little.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do this with haste, before the place is evacuated, for it is customary to evacuate the place in many men during a small operation.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If therefore you see that it has already been evacuated, then do not repeat the operation on it altogether, for to you it is nothing.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And place something of oil on it afterwards, for it will soften the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And this is better than oil alone, and than other oils as well.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And administer the same mixture of oil with dung in all your phlebotomies, whereby it prevents the flow of blood into the veins: and they make a tairiaca alfarach, and sagnena, when it is applied from one of these upon the place.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	Blood is purified and resolved when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	But if it happens that a large void occurs at the place of phlebotomy, for this happens often, especially to those who are not phlebotomized except for that kind, or there is a small opening in the vein, then do it with haste and put over the place a sponge soaked in water and salt, heated beforehand for a while: and tie it up at one hour: because it is dissolved.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And you should also do that after the blood has been drawn from the vein itself, with its completion, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	But if something remains in the place after three days of discoloration or greenishness, it does not do harm: and if you wish, put something on it that is an aloe, or a dissolving myrrh: or something from the juice of mentha, that is calamine, or similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And many times indeed things happen with ulcers and swellings during phlebotomy at the basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Put therefore your hand over it then, and if you feel a softness under the pressure of your hand over it, then that swelling is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore, as you put something on it because we said so.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood may flow from that artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But apply a plaster to it with the same ointment where there is inflammation, so that the place may harden.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat this (the ulcer) with the rest of the treatment until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary that you drain all people from blood according to the amount of their virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what appears as a burning color over the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it be released until it turns red; and similarly if you see it thick, then let it be released until it becomes thin; and similarly if it is sharp, then let it be released until its sharpness is removed.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary that to him who is full, be strong and needs the extraction of blood instead of one, so that the venesection may be amplified and it be a wide phlebotomy; and to him who is weak, its opposite.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary that he drain it in the places and that there be a narrow opening; and that which is given in venesection of veins is better if there be a reversed section, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of venesection is safe from the flow of blood and from the cut of the nerve; and it is more praiseworthy and safer than venesection by length and breadth.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And to whom it is customary to come at the time of phlebotomy, one should take food before phlebotomy with a small amount of bread infused in grape juice, or siccanaif, if heated: and draw out from him three times or four from his blood.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if his complexion is unfrozen, then let him take before phlebotomy bread infused in grape syrup, or in honey syrup with spices, or in fragrant syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	But if it happens that phlebotomy occurs at the time of bloodletting, and it is the cause of his excessive blood discharge: then let him take in a drink water of flesh, and a subtle fragrant syrup: and he shall use its fragrance with algae, and linseed to bind his chest with them: and he shall use what we have said regarding division in the chapter on phlebotomy for evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	But if he wants to let his arm loose and discharge his blood again: it is necessary for him who has phlebotomy because of excessive evacuation, and whose strength is weak, that he should gradually release his blood over the span of several days according to the amount of his virtue.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	But if he truly wants to let his arm loose and discharge his blood again, and it is his strong body: then he shall do that after seven hours, or nine from the first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	But if he wants to attract blood from his body to the opposite side to which it inclines: then he must have him bleed on the second day, or on the third.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whose true body the blood is already much heated and thickened, and makes fever occur: it is necessary that from him blood be extracted in a single vein, and a great quantity of blood be drawn out: and the opening should be made until bleeding occurs; after which, while you are preserving all phlebotomy conditions, and placing your hand on his pulse with the flow of blood, lest death occur at the place of bleeding.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Many times because when he doesn't know, and falls due to negligence.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it should not be when you need to cut the arm and draw blood second, since the vein opening is already closed, and it's hard for the blood to come out, so you might do something rashly, and if it needs to be stretched quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For that is very bad, dismiss him until the barber comes second.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or remove it carefully with the barbering technique of blood clotting at the vein opening, and put something salty dissolved in water on top of it.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And put something from the Tyrian purple or saffron on top of it, and put it under compression with linen, until blood comes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If the vein is already closed, then dismiss it, and do not press on it, until the wound heals.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	But if necessity forces you to cut the blood second, and there is no excuse, then either cut it at that place again above it, or in another arm on a different vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	The veins of the arm are cut at the location of the Fusca and Basilica, when they cannot be found, because it is composed of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of its cutting is that it inserts his diseased hand into warm water until it becomes red and the vein appears clearly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then wrap it with a bandage, but tie it with a moderate constricting pressure.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then the second cut is made with a slow turning, not laterally nor according to length: and let the opening be wide, and let your phlebotomy be as much as the phlebotomies above the hand joint.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If blood is prohibited from flowing out, then iterate your hand in warm water and release the blood to flow into the water until you achieve what is necessary for you.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	If however you are in summer days, then you excuse yourself from iterating your hand in warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And it is put down that the course of blood in warm water should be done in winter time.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the phlebotomy of this vein is safer for all veins, because it is not under a pulseful vein, nor a nerve.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	Actually the phlebotomy of the right hand is called Salusatella, and it compares with the illnesses of the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of phlebotomy of that vein is such that you should tie your hand tightly with a bandage, or your own hand, after you have inserted it into warm water, until the vein inflates and you can feel it very strongly.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then make the incision in a reversed direction.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you make the cut completely, it will not harm him much at all.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And preserve yourself, lest your last hand be used with the phlebotomist.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Under that vein there are nerves of the fingers uncovered from the flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then iterate your hand into warm water again, and release the blood to flow in it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	Because if you do not iterate her again into warm water, the blood clots in the vein opening and prevents its flow.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When therefore you extract from the blood the amount of necessity, then put oil and salt over the vein, so that it will not quickly congeal.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And similarly it is fitting that you should make cuts with every straight branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The true method of the venesection of his disease is from the left hand, because it refers to the sufferings of the spleen; and do this in venesection as you did in the second procedure equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The saphenous method of venesection is for the diseases that are in the lower part of the body, such as the complaints of women, retention of menstruation, and weaknesses of the kidneys, old ulcers on the shoulders and thighs, and similar afflictions.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of his venesection is that he introduces his diseased foot into warm water; and makes it rub against himself until the vein opens up: and ties above the ankle with a ligature.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And the vein is located under the heel, appearing to be opposite the thumb; and branches out from it on the face of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Therefore he takes it from the larger branch of his vein or at the heel where they congregate, because it is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	But if he takes it from the face of the foot, then beware of the nerves that are under it, on the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your venesection there, as if you were cutting into it from the opposite side, so that it becomes a Nesil's venesection.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If however the issue is that there will be an exit of blood, then put his foot into warm water, and let the blood run into it until it is emptied.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	But if the venesectioner erred in his first incision, then he should proceed with caution and continue with the venesection towards the upper part for a little while, because the place is safe, and you do not fear a bad outcome, when you beware of the nerves, as we said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly with the peroneal vein of the other foot.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The veins are however located, as we have said, next to the heel from the forest side.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And its remedy for venesection is, due to the pain in the heel, when it's caused by hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of its venesection is that it must enter the sick man into the bath and hasten it; and tie his leg from the side of the heel up to the upper part of the calcaneus with a fine rope, for it does not appear except through this.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When therefore it appears, then the venesection of it is according to what skill you can manage or through inversion; and it is better either to cut into it with an incision or to remove it by section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For its location is safe and itself is found hidden in many men.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	But if you cannot find it and do not appear at all to the sense, then remove some of its branches, and that one is what appears on the back of the foot, and towards the ear; and beware of the nerves, and make run a course from the blood according to its quantity as much as possible.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then remove the bandage and put skin over the location of venesection, and tie up the place.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	It heals quickly.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	Of ventilation and its quality of use.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter 98
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Venoms are formed from horns, and from air, and from urine.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And Ventosation is done in two modes.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	With scarification and bleeding extraction: and the other is ventosation without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this ventosation which is without scarification is done in two modes.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or else it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And ventosations which are administered with scarification and blood extraction are located in fourteen places of the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	And of these there are fourteen places of the body. One is Ventosatio Alnocrati, and it is last on the head; and Alkehel, and it is middle on the neck; and ventosae Alhagdahim, and they are two laminae on the neck from both sides at once; and ventosae menti, and it is under the mandible in the lower part of the mouth; and ventosae duarum spatularum, and they are middle on both arms; and ventosae Alachosos above the end of the tail; and ventosae duorum focilium, and they are middle on both legs; and ventosae duorum crurium; and ventosae duarum cauillarum.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And ventosation does not draw blood from the small veins scattered in the flesh, and because of this it does not acquire the virtue from them, as is the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Nor should ventosation be administered whether with or without fire when there is some disease that arises from overfilling, until the whole body has been evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If necessity forces us to perform ventosation because of illness or by custom, we administer it at all times in the beginning of the month, at the end of it, and in the middle of it, and at any other time.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	Because it is from humans that whoever multiplies in him when his blood multiplies until he needs the extraction of his head through cauterization catches it in his own head.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And from them is he who catches a swelling and redness on his face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And from them is he who catches itching on his face, and forehead, and darkness, and weakness in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And from them is he who scratches the place of cauterization of his own.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And from them is whose laughter multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And from them is he who catches a taste of blood in his mouth, or aphthous tongue, and spits out the blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And from them is whose sleep multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And from them is he who sees blood and redness, and wounds, and plagues, and such things as those.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When therefore we see something from them, and it is precisely on the third day of the month: then let us perform cauterization afterwards, after they have passed two days, or three.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The measure of cauterization on the neck is: because it conveys to heaviness in the head, and what flows out to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	But indeed, it should be so that it is done after evacuation of the entire body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this cauterization is also at the place of the cephalic phlebotomy.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not allowed to use it on one who has a cold complexion, or in whom there is catarrh.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	He did not cause her great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And because of this, it should not be that they use them when old, and in whose head there are cold pains.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	But if he is often applied to her, forgetfulness occurs over him.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And because of this, you should instruct the person who performs the operation to place his hand on it for a while with the windy side towards the lower part, fearing that through the process of forgetfulness.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Ventosation or Alchehel is the place of phlebotomy for the foot, and phlebotomy for the basilica, because it conveys a stench, and a constriction of the breath, and a split in the instrument of the breath, and coughing, and repletion.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it should be that the Ventosation of Alchehel is more forcefully applied, because if it is placed lower, it causes weakness in the heart and the stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Ventosation of al-hagdahim conveys pain to accidents in the head, and ophthalmia, and hemigranee, and perforation, and pain in the roots of the teeth: and it is a place for phlebotomy of the basilica.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it should be that you instruct the Ventosator not to place his hand with scarring before he touches: so that he does not strike an artery and cause a flow of blood.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	Ventosation under the chin conveys a liquor to the mouth, and corruption of the gums, and similar diseases that are in the mouth: and it is placed as phlebotomy of the al-Heirikh, which are in two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	Ventosation of spoons conveys to the al-chafacham, which is made from a convulsion, and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	The suturing of the interior parts of two flanks, brings together the conjunction of phlebotomy of three veins: Basilicae, and those of the heel and head: because it itself attracts blood from all those fine veins which are in the flesh; and these small veins attract those other smaller veins from the larger ones until attraction reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And it is necessary that you instruct the Suturer, not to proceed excessively in incision: for the place is stripped of flesh, and under it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	But the suturing which stitches over haemorrhoids of the anus, and wounds below, is done.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it is necessary that you instruct the Suturer, to be very careful and to make a great suture, and of silver: because the place needs strong suction, and possibly the fine sutures are broken; and the incision must be made by a great incision.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	The sutures of the legs are diminished by a manifest decrease: because they attract blood from the whole body, and relieve old pains in the kidneys, uterus, and bladder: they provoke menstruation, and relieve flatulence, and stand in place of phlebotomy of both saphenous veins and anococcygeal vein.
